titleStmt.title: The Articles of the giuing ouer of the large, ample, and imperiall cittie of Groning also the Articles and conditions, whervpon His Highnes, and the Honorable William Ludowick, Earle of Nassow, at this present, with the aduice of the counsell of the Estates of the Vnited Prouinces, are content to agree vnto, for reducing and reconciliation of the said cittie of Groning : likewise the agreement, concluded between His Highnes, and the chiefe lieutenant Laukema, with the captaines, commaunders, and common souldiours, beeing in garrison within the fore-sayd cittie / doone the xxi. and xxii. of July, 1594 ; with repetition ofthe besieging of the same.

titleStmt.title: The Articles of the giuing ouer of the large, ample, and imperiall cittie of Groning also the Articles and conditions, whervpon His Highnes, and the Honorable William Ludowick, Earle of Nassow, at this present, with the aduice of the counsell of the Estates of the Vnited Prouinces, are content to agree vnto, for reducing and reconciliation of the said cittie of Groning : likewise the agreement, concluded between His Highnes, and the chiefe lieutenant Laukema, with the captaines, commaunders, and common souldiours, beeing in garrison within the fore-sayd cittie / doone the xxi. and xxii. of July, 1594 ; with repetition ofthe besieging of the same.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Articles of the giuing ouer of the large, ample, and imperiall Cittie of GRONING.

AlÅ¿o the Articles and conditions, whervpon his Highnes, and the honorable William Ludowick Earle of NaÅ¿Å¿ow, at this preÅ¿ent, with the aduice of the CounÅ¿ell of the EÅ¿tates of the vnited Prouinces, are content to agree vnto: for reducing and reconciliation of the Citty, Cittizens, and Indwellers of the Å¿aid Cittie of Groning.
LikewiÅ¿e the agreement, concluded between his Highnes, and the chiefe Lieutenant Laukema, with the Captaines, Commaunders, and common Souldiours, beeing in GarriÅ¿on within the fore-Å¿ayd Cittie.

p.hi: Doone the xxi. and xxii. of July, 1594. With repetition of the beÅ¿ieging of the Å¿ame.

figure.figDesc: depiction of the capture of Groningen

div.p: Printed at London by Iohn VVoolfe.

div.head: Â¶The Articles of the giuing ouer of the imperiall Cittie of Groning.
div.p: THE excellent Prince and Lorde Morrice of NaÅ¿Å¿ow, &c. hauing reÅ¿cued Coeuerden, where the common Enemie with all his power on foote and on horÅ¿ebacke, had lyne al the Winter, and Å¿trengthened himÅ¿elfe with Å¿undrie Trenches, againÅ¿t the inÅ¿urrection of our people, hath notwithÅ¿tanding not tarryed the comming of our Campe, but hath left the CaÅ¿tle of Coeuerden, with all her Trenches and Campes.

Which done, his Highnes came before Groning, the 20. of May, viewed the Cittie, and Å¿ummoned it. Their aunÅ¿were was, that they Å¿hould firÅ¿t lye a yeere & a day before it, and then Å¿houlde Å¿ummon the Å¿ame. There Å¿houlde you haue Å¿Ã©ene many kindes of cariages, in very great quantitie, of rafters, poÅ¿tes, Deales, plancks and boords, where-with many Ships were laden. There was tenne Ships Å¿ent from Gorcum with boordes, beÅ¿ides many hundreds which came from Swoll and other places, and were beÅ¿poken.

There came to the Campe before Groning, froÌ„ my Lords the States, vnder the conduct of his Highnes, about one hundred and fortie EnÅ¿ignes of footemen: as high Dutch, EngliÅ¿hmen, Scots, Netherlanders, and FrÃ©eÅ¿landers. The FreeÅ¿landers vnder the conduct of William Earle of NaÅ¿Å¿ow. There was viij. EnÅ¿ignes preÅ¿ently Å¿ent before the Forte at Aurikeizill, to take in the Å¿ame: for they held out Å¿toutly, and attended for fiue EnÅ¿ignes, that came with bridges & Ladders for the aÅ¿Å¿ault.

And Å¿tanding readie to employ all their might thereon, there came three other EnÅ¿ignes from the other Å¿ide, with bridges, many buÌ„dles of BulruÅ¿hes bound together in Å¿acks, pitched and nayled vnder Tables made of Deale-bords, ouer which they ranne to the wall of the Fort. They which had
no Ladders, did Å¿ticke their daggers in, and climed vp by them. The people Å¿Ã©eing that they were ouer-fallen, cryed for grace, but it was too late: for they had Å¿poken very obprobrious words to the DromÅ¿ter, wherefore they were all ouer-come, and of one hundred and thirty, there was not fiue left aliue. Which was no Å¿mall feare to them of Groningâ–ª as alÅ¿o the driuing out of their folke out of the Trenche at Hogherbrug. So that they of Groning, were conÅ¿trained to driue their Cattell vnder the Towne wall, where they could not all be kept, but Å¿ome were fedde with Hay in the Cittie. There was about foure-Å¿core of thoÅ¿e without, which were taken by our men.

After this, they iÅ¿Å¿ued forth of the Citty in Å¿undry places vpon our men, with the helpe of fiue EnÅ¿ignes of Souldiers, that lay in Shutendiepe, which place is Å¿trongly defended Å¿euerally from the Citty, lying vpon ye water called the Vaertâ–ª ) which the Coronell made at that time. With this their iÅ¿Å¿uing out, they did our folkes very much harme. But after we had made our Trenches, digged our Lope-ditches, & Å¿trengthened the Å¿ame, their left they of their iÅ¿Å¿uing out.

Great was the carefulnes of his Highnes and my Lords the States, in the fortifying and making Å¿ure of our Campe, towards all quarters, where any feare was of aÅ¿Å¿aulting. And then employing all their force againÅ¿t the Citty, with diging and placing of their Ordinance. Yea, in thrÃ©e places they came to their very wall, Å¿o that in two places, they digged and vndermined twenty and thirtie foote within their Wall. They within reÅ¿ted not, but defended themÅ¿elues: inÅ¿omuch that through their manifold Å¿hooting, there was founde aboue two thouÅ¿and pellets.

Heereby is to be coniectured, that they Å¿hotte foure thouÅ¿and Å¿hotte at the leaÅ¿t, with great Ordinaunce. For at the beginning they were prouided with foure hundred Barrells of powder, which were leÅ¿Å¿ned to fiftie, and yet were not they of the beÅ¿t.

Vppon the Gate called the Herren Port, were eight great peeces placed, and wholie Å¿hot of. There were many houÅ¿es
Å¿haken, and Å¿poyled with the Ordinance, and Å¿omtimes with fire-works out of the Campe, and balles of wild-fire, which in Å¿under places did Å¿ette theyr houÅ¿es on fire: where-vppon preÅ¿ently followed pellets of Å¿tone, and hayle-Å¿hot mingled with wild-fire. Whereby the hearts of the Cittizens began heere and there to faint, and were brought to Å¿uch point, that they tooke pledges one of another.

The Rulers were brought to Å¿uch extremety, and to adgrauiate the matter, (not Å¿o much through the beÅ¿ieging, but by certaine Souldiers of Sluiten-deepe, which were let into the Citty,) that they were forced to hold their handes, which made a rumor in the Citty, inÅ¿omuch that Å¿ome loÅ¿t theyr lyues by it. Thys being Å¿tilled and pacified, the Souldiours had afterwards no good reÅ¿t or quietnes for want of Å¿leepe, by reaÅ¿on of theyr continuall watching. The chiefe of them was occaÅ¿ion heereby to write to Don Verdugo, for a Å¿upply of Souldiours, munition, and money. One of the carryers of theÅ¿e Letters was Å¿laine, and hanged vp againÅ¿t the Cittie: the other was pardoned, becauÅ¿e hee bewrayed the Å¿ecrets of the Citty.

Vpon the Roundell (which was made long agoe, and in the time of Duke Daline, called The CaÅ¿tle,) were alÅ¿o eyght great pÃ©eces of Ordinance planted, one of the corners wherof was wholy Å¿hotte downe, and Å¿o made vnfenceable. His Highnes through his diligence and endeuour going heere about to Å¿ee the manner, a Å¿hotte light vpon his Trench, that thoÅ¿e which Å¿toode harde by him, were thereby Å¿princkled in their faces.

One of the three mynes vnder the Å¿ayde Roundell, named Rauelin, was digged, which beeing perceiued by them of the Citty, was countermined, by which our men entred, placing of their powder, and alarme preÅ¿ently giuen. WhilÅ¿t they of the Citty were Å¿etting of their watch at the Å¿aide Rauelin, the powder was by a traine Å¿uddainly Å¿et on fire, with Å¿uch thundering noyÅ¿e and duÅ¿t, that for the Å¿pace of three houres, one man coulde not Å¿Ã©e another. The chiefeÅ¿t Lieutenant was alÅ¿o Å¿layne.

The Reader may well thinke, howe armes, legges and and whole bodies of men, were blowne away in the ayre, for two of them fell into our Trenches, wherof one was yet aliue. Thys Bulwarke brake and fell downe, according as we wiÅ¿hed, and hath made a braue bancke. AlÅ¿o the way filled vp betweene Rauelin and the Cittie, our men crept in, without loÅ¿ing of any one man: where they founde Å¿ixe peeces of Ordinance, and certaine men wrapped vp in the earth, which were yet aliue. The Å¿ame day in the Euening in Å¿etting of our watch, we loÅ¿t eyght Souldiours.

They in the Cittie Å¿eeing this, were at their wits end, as if the day of Iudgement had beene come. Straightwaies Iohn den Boer, or Iohn the Clowne, was Å¿ent out with a Taber and a pype, yet that day all was not ended. But the next day, they of the Cittie, vpon good aÅ¿Å¿urance and promiÅ¿e of his Highnes, came forth in foure Å¿euerall companies, that is to Å¿ay, the Clergie, the MagiÅ¿trates, the chiefeÅ¿t of the Souldiours, and the men of Occupations. One of theÌ„ would not truÅ¿t another. Heerevpon his Highnes Å¿aid vnto them, Looke what you agree to, is wholie giuen you through my liberalitie: for I count my Å¿elfe aÅ¿Å¿ured of the Citty. In the end, after many debatings, the xxij. day of Iulie, theÅ¿e Articles following were agreed vpon.

list.item: 1. FirÅ¿t, that his HighneÅ¿Å¿e for the firÅ¿t time, may diÅ¿place the MagiÅ¿trate, and place him again, and the Å¿worne Communaltie, at his pleaÅ¿ure.

2. That the Gildes or Companies Å¿hall in that reÅ¿pect, be Å¿et a Å¿ide, that they Å¿hall haue nothing to Å¿ay in the policie of the Cittie. But the CounÅ¿ell Å¿hall deale therein with the Å¿worne Communaltie, Å¿uch as the CounÅ¿ell will vÅ¿e therevnto.
3. That his Highnes may put Souldiours into the Cittie at his pleaÅ¿ure: but yet in Å¿uch manner as is vÅ¿ed in FreeÅ¿land.
4. That the Cittie Å¿hall renounce the King, and declare him their enemie. And alÅ¿o bee Å¿eaÅ¿ed with ImpoÅ¿ts or any others, as the Citties in FreeÅ¿elande.
5. That no other Religion be Å¿uffered, but onlie the true reformed Religion.
6. That during theÅ¿e warres, his Highnes Å¿hal yeerely chooÅ¿e out fiue of the Å¿worne Communalty, which Å¿hall appoynt the CounÅ¿ell.
7. That the GarriÅ¿on of the Enemie Å¿hall paÅ¿Å¿e ouer the Rhine, leauing their EnÅ¿ignes behind theÌ„. And Å¿wearing in thrÃ©e moneths not to Å¿erue on this Å¿ide the Å¿ame.

div.p: But his Highnes afterwards, at the interceÅ¿Å¿ion of certaine Gentlemen, bid the EnÅ¿ignes to be giuen them at their departing.

Touching all other Articles, the Å¿ame Å¿hall remaine at the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the generall EÅ¿tates. The Lord giue his Highnes long life, that thereby all they may be forced which exerciÅ¿e SpaniÅ¿h tyrannie, and oppreÅ¿Å¿e the good.
Almightie GOD be thanked for his grace and fauour, and thys great victorie, for euer and euer. Amen.
